Students and Society: Represent York

30/04/2021

Kirsten Murray chats to Aphra and Senah, the students behind Represent York, ahead of their upcoming Symposium.

Image by Instagram: @representyork

By Kirsten Murray

After months of planning and hard work, Represent York is taking place from the 4th-7th May â€“ a weeklong symposium at the University that aims to educate about topics of race, anti-racism, and racism. Passionate for all students to have their voices heard, and to spread awareness as to how the University can actively contribute to anti-racism, students Aphra and Senah were keen to be involved with the campaign, and the project has only grown from strength to strength.

We are all aware of the events of last summer and the magnitude of the Black Lives Matter campaign. Aphra emphasises that â€œthe time to talk about race and racism is all the time, especially whilst racism continues to existâ€. Minutes before Derek Chauvin, George Floydâ€™s murderer, was convicted as guilty, Ma'Khia Bryant was shot by police in Columbus, Ohio. The movement may have gained momentum last summer, but institutionalised racism is ongoing, as Senah explains: â€œThe Black Lives Matter movement was a catalyst for campaigns like ours.â€ Represent York provides a platform to translate these conversations of race into our community at York, openly addressing issues of representation on campus and continuing to educate non-POC people on the reality of being a person of colour at university. As the pair rightly state, â€œthe â€˜perfect timeâ€™ to start this campaign would have been anytime, but the timing does serve as an opportunity to champion these conversations while people are listening.â€

â€œEvents like â€˜Represent Yorkâ€™ are important because they provide the inspiration and hope towards ensuring that everyone feels represented here. We hope this symposium inspires people to continue doing the work even when it is over, because being anti-racist and caring about these issues is a long-life commitment.â€ â€“ Aphra



Senah, who was formerly the Director of the Norman Rea Gallery, explains how Represent York was originally led by herself and Aphra, former President of York Anti-Racist Collective Society, and originated as a fundraiser that focused on expanding the representation of artists at university â€“ but then it grew. The University took the students on to expand the project further, allowing them to continue their work on diversity, starting with the â€˜Represent York Fundraiserâ€™ which ran from last December to March. Despite setting a goal of Â£3,500, the fundraiser raised an incredible Â£4,795 â€“ with half being donated to anti-racist charity, The Racist Justice Network, and the other half pledged to help commission local artists of colour in York. The University also donated a further Â£1,750 to commission artists, highlighting the huge success of the campaign, Aphra comments â€œI think it has left a great legacy in York.â€

But how has this money helped? The money has had a huge impact on the Universityâ€™s art collection, both helping to diversify the artwork and financially supporting a local artistic community which has struggled so much during the pandemic. Senah explains: â€œThe focus â€“ from the artistic perspective â€“ was to address the idea that the collection in its state before the fundraiser was not reflective of its locality. The University of York prides itself on its diversity, so the art it owns should reflect its students. As a History of Art student, a person of colour and an international student, I wanted to see myself reflected in the collection. York is not as male, white and English as the collection suggested â€“ it now includes a broader scope of what it means to be â€˜from York.â€

Despite Covid restrictions, the team at Represent York have planned a completely Covid-secure symposium, with all talks taking place over Zoom, and the in-person art exhibition occurring in Covid-secure conditions. Each day will tackle a different theme: led by Chair of the Race Equality Coordination Group at UoY, Professor Kiran Trehan, Tuesday begins with a discussion on race, racism and anti-racism at the University of York and in higher education. Wednesday will focus on decolonising the curriculum, while Thursday will explore race and mental health.

Discussing these areas of focus in more detail, Aphra emphasises the importance of decolonising the curriculum, as it points out both the things that students are not learning, or how the things we do learn come predominantly from a Westernised lens that does not involve POC. Senah continues, adding that many departments are already doing work to decolonise their curriculums, and they wish to draw attention to this. Wednesdayâ€™s event will focus on decolonising the curriculum from an arts and humanities perspective, as well as a scientific one. Senah states â€œDecolonisation does not have to purely be insular, based within individual departments and thus potentially limited in its scope â€“ part of the aim of the symposium is to draw awareness to the idea that a course can even attempt to decolonise itself. Departments and students can support each other in these efforts, and it begins by conversation.â€

The pandemic has taken a toll on everyoneâ€™s mental health and Represent York will further conversations around the mental health of POC and how race plays a part in this. Aphra points out that through social media we are constantly shown the death of black people: â€œseeing someone like you become a hashtag â€“ itâ€™s quite a crushing feeling.â€ Similarly, constantly experiencing institutional racism and microaggressions has a huge affect on POCâ€™s mental health, and Represent York hopes to show students that there is support available. Open Door Practitioner, Yasmine Clarke, will be present to discuss how the universityâ€™s mental health services can ensure that they take race into consideration as well as providing a space for students to share their thoughts. Senah emphasises that â€œstudents can often feel uncomfortable speaking about their race on campus â€“ in regards to mental health (and potentially any race-related negative experiences that may impact mental health), therefore it is incredibly important to provide support on campus for students to speak on their realities.â€

â€œTalking about race does not have to be difficult; by normalising these conversations we can move forward as a University that champions its students and their interests - and itâ€™s time to address race more forwardly.â€ â€“ Senah



As well as the talks, an art exhibition will also accompany the symposium, being unveiled on Tuesday, with the winners announced on Friday. Because of her involvement in the Norman Rea Gallery, Senah was keen to continue an artistic focus: â€œthe inclusion of art was important to me, as I feel strongly that art is incredibly powerful in conveying a message.â€ She explains how â€œthe art exhibition has taken on the focus of wanting to showcase the personal reflections of race and representation that students at York have. Through this, I think we can connect with the concept of intersectionality beyond academic discussions, but through a visual lens.â€

Word has clearly spread, as Aphra and Senah have received some fantastic art submissions and are really excited to display the artwork next week. People are clearly keen to engage with topics of race and representation and wish to be able to do so in the safety of a university environment.

So what does the future hold? Aphra explains: â€œSenah and I are trying to ensure that the Symposium is not just a one-week event but rather has a long-lasting impact. It would be great if this were a yearly event. One of the things that we want to ensure is that practical things are implemented as a result of this symposium. A lot of things around decolonising the curriculum are occurring at the university, but they seem to be quite detached, so we hope that we can bring more people together and also let more people know about this work.â€ The girls hope to reach out to other departments and groups, working with them to ensure action continues to be taken and events like Represent York, in symposium, exhibition, and fundraiser form, become regular occurrences, and can occur in person in the future.

Through hard work and innovative ideas, Aphra, Senah, YUSU and the University have created an incredible event which has led to positive action. Both Aphra and Senah are graduating this year, therefore they want to create as much of an impact as they can and lay the foundations for future discussions and actions.

It is easy to get involved â€“ simply attend the talks! As well as speakers, the events aim to facilitate discussions within attendees to hear what students and staff have to say.

To find out more and keep up to date with future events from Represent York, you can visit their website www.representyork.com, follow them on Instagram @representyorkÂ and check out theirÂ Facebook page for free tickets to the Symposium.
